unit_learning_outcomes.description: Explain macroeconomic and industry analysis, equity valuation and financial statement analysis.
Work productively in a group to investigate a finance scenario or problem and communicate the findings and/or recommendations professionally.
Formulate derivatives strategies to modify portfolio risk-return attributes.
Illustrate the theory and empirical applications of asset pricing models.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Preparation for lectures, tutorials and assessment tasks.

enrolment_rules.description: 50cp at 1000 level or above including ((AFIN100 or AFIN102 or AFIN1002 or ACST152 or ACST1052) and (ACCG100 or ACCG1000 or ACCG106) and (STAT150 or STAT1250 or STAT170 or STAT1170 or STAT171 or STAT1371)) or (ACST252 or ACST2052)

assessments.description: A 2.5 hour open book online exam will be held during the University Examination period.
The online quiz will consist of 5 to 10 questions and will be available on iLearn. Please use the quiz result as an indicator of whether you are progressing satisfactorily in the unit.

Students will work collaboratively, in groups, to conduct an analysis of an investment scenario or problem (worth 10%). Students will then be required to write an individual report of 500 to 1000 words (worth 10%).
An open book mid session test of 90 minutes will be held to give students practice on a summative task and to provide feedback on their progress midway through the session.
A closed book mid session test of 90 minutes will be held to give students practice on a summative task and to provide feedback on their progress midway through the session.
A closed book exam of 2.5 hours will be held during the University Examination Period.

Session 2, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 2, Special circumstances
Session 1, Special circumstances
data.description: This unit covers concepts in investment management including asset pricing, fixed income, industry analysis and derivatives contracts. Students will acquire the analytical tools and financial theory necessary for making sound investment decisions and understanding the methodologies by which financial securities are valued. Students learn the principles of modern portfolio theories and apply them to empirical asset pricing models.
data.title: Investments

description: This unit covers concepts in investment management including asset pricing, fixed income, industry analysis and derivatives contracts. Students will acquire the analytical tools and financial theory necessary for making sound investment decisions and understanding the methodologies by which financial securities are valued. Students learn the principles of modern portfolio theories and apply them to empirical asset pricing models.
